12.4164
BEiRUT
Dear F°
and F.,
Friday Dec. 4th, 1964•
We were
invited to a very fine dinner last
night by a V-P of the
Continental Oil Co.
It was good to meet a
sizeable group
of the American community.
This morning Debby went
to the "SUQ" with some ladies she met at dinner.
"SUQ" is the
Arabic word for bazaar.
She bought a bracelet
and the next dgy,
Sat. Dec. 5th, she talked me into going around.
You'd know that
you were not in Tiffany's.
that evening we had dinner with the
Boyntons and the Bojonells, he is PAA #1 in Athens and was over here
on a brief business
trip.
We were glad to see
them again.
Boynton
had just come bauk fron Cyprus.
He said externally at least, Cyprus
never had it so good.
Every hotel and cafe full every night with
free-spending
United Nations people, Army officers and newspaper
reporters fron all over the world.
Sun. Dec. 6th.
I have stayed in bed all day trying unsuccessfully
to shake a cold.
Tomorrow we leave for Hong Kong.
I feel a little
sad at not going to 8,000 foot level Teheran and
some what lower
but colder Afghanastan as we had more or less planned.
Guess I am
not tough like my old friend Phil Ball.
No doubt most of you have
heard this story but a good story is always worth repeating ( if you
don't do it too often).
Back in 1927 Mr. Ball bought a Ryan airplane
He asked me to recommend a pilot and I did.
This particular man,
Frank kgan Dunn, was about as homely and as tough as theyp come
but
a good safe pilot.
When I sent Frank up to Mr. Ball's office for an
interview I said
"Frank, make it perfectly clear right from the
start that Mr. Ball is boss on the ground but that you are boss in the
sky as well as deciding whether or not you should venture
therein".
Frank went on upstairs and about 20 minutes later cane back by my
desk in the old State National Bank.
He
said " Gee, I've net some
tough guys but
we nade a deal, we'll
get along all right".
Another
five minutes
and Mr. Ball cane
down "Say Bix, where in h-- did
you find that
porch climber?"
They were together until Mr. Ball's
death
(in bed)
some 15 years later.
When the Ryan was ready for
delivery
they went out to San Diego together..
Frank was checked
out on
the plane and they took off for El Paso.
Mr. Ball said
"Frank,
climb up to 12,000 feet".
Frank demurred because it was a
slow
climb with a full load but he went on up to 12,000 feet and
ran "down hill" into El Paso.
As they were having dinner together
that night Frank said "Mr.
Ball why did you want me to go to 12,000
feet?"
Mr. Ball said "Well Frank,
I didn't want to worryy
you
but
I don't mind telling you now.
My doctor told me hath
that if I
went
up
to 10,000 feet I'd drop dead.
I knew that he didn't know
what he was
talking about so I
spotted him 2000 feet and as you
know I'm still around".
Well I just do not have as much nerve as
old man Ball.
When perhaps you can't get enough air to keep the
old
pump going its better to play safe.
I had another reason for
going to Teheran.
Years ago in New York, I got a call from a
White House
contact asking me to meet a Mr. Pahlevi at theairport,
show him around, give him a good
time, "quite important" Wabhington
said.
So I met Mr. Pahlevi who was a most friendly younguan,
went through the hangars, he tried the link trainer,
and did.
quite
well, we had the usual
buffet lunch where what you don't spill is
your
own with a group of executives and pibots and the young man
whose Oxford English was better the
